Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Request for Ground-Verification of the Luquillo Critical Zone Observatory LIDAR Overflight
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will be a ground verification campaign for airborne LiDAR data gathering over the Luquillo Critical Zone Observatory (LCZO). This airborne LiDAR will cover representative research watersheds of the LCZO and extend from the US Forest Service Luquillo Experimental Forest to the surrounding coastal areas. During the airborne data collection a complete set of carefully located (using GPS) biophysical measurements, such as diameter of trees, canopy closure, leaf-area index, and crown height will enable a much more effective modeling of the watershed topography and processes from the LiDAR point cloud. Because the over flight has been scheduled for the summer of 2010, the ground verification campaign must be conducted at the same time.

Airborne LiDAR is similar to radar, except that it operates at a much shorter wavelength for detecting small-scale changes in topography. However, to be most effective, ground-based measurements must be done simultaneously to map relevant features such as vegetation height and type, since the LiDAR signal will be received from the top of the tree canopy as well as from the ground. This project will accomplish the task in the Luquillo Critical Zone Observatory to insure that the research progam at this NSF-supported facility will be able to document small changes in watershed characteristics that are the result of climatically-driven weathering and erosion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the summer of 2010 (June to September), two master graduate students Brian Moore and Jennifer Frey from the University of Southern Mississippi, under the guidance of Dr. Fred Scatena, Professor and chair at the University of Pennsylvania, and Dr. Wei Wu, Assistant Professor at the University of Southern Mississippi, measured geographic coordinates, topographic attributes, % canopy cover, canopy height, stand basal area, leaf area index, and stand composition at 171 locations in the Luquillo Critical Zone Observatory (LCZO). These measurements will provide ground truth data for the calibration of a Critical Zone Observatory (CZO) Network sponsored LiDAR flight and facilitate the development of algorithms to derive topographic surfaces and three dimensional structures of trees using the LiDAR images. The sample locations covered the three upland forest types (Tabonuco at the low elevations, Colorado at the middle elevations, Palm at the steep slope and poorly drained soil) and mangrove forest at the coast. The locations also covered the range of topographic conditions (slope and aspect, ridge or valley), elevation, and aspect of the LCZO. In order to optimize sampling efforts, most of the sampling locations were also sites where soil samples were collected as part of the LCZO soil network, or were permanent plots for ecological studies in the Luquillo Long-Term Ecological Research (Luquillo LTER). The sampling methods followed the protocol developed by the CZO network.

 

In addition to training two graduate students on sampling design, data collection using different equipment at highly heterogeneous ecosystem, and data analysis using computer, we have provided the major results to the CZO network and posted them on the LCZO web page (http://www.sas.upenn.edu/lczo/). The major findings are:

1)     Average LAI was higher in the Tabonuco forest (4.62) at the low elevations compared to the Colorado forest (2.14) at the higher elevations.

2)     The percentage of canopy coverage is high in all types of forests while Tabonuco, Colorado, palm and mangrove ranked high to low in canopy height.

3)     The average and median basal area for Tabonuco forest and Colorado forest are similar. The minimum, maximum, median and average basal areas measured in the palm forest were larger than the other forest types. On average, the basal area was lowest in the mangrove forest.

4)     Among the variables that were measured, the canopy height would be the tree characteristics that can best differentiate the different types of forest.
